questions.text: What is implied if a drug has more renal clearance than GFR?

choices.text: Drug is reabsorbed by the renal tubules
Drug is secreted in the renal tubules
Drug is excreted in renal tubules
Drug is neither excreted nor reabsorbed in renal tubules

questions.solution:
If drug has more renal clearance than GFR, then drug is secreted in renal tubules. 

Excretion rate= (filtration rate- reabsorption rate)+ secretion rate.

The clearance of the substance:

  • Equals the GFR if there is no net tubular secretion or reabsorption.
  • Exceeds the GFR if there is net tubular secretion.
  • Less than the GFR if there is net tubular reabsorption.

questions.text: Choose the correct option.

choices.text: Inulin is completely secreted and never reabsorbed.
Glucose is completely reabsorbed in DCT.
PAH at any plasma concentration is completely filtered and secreted.

questions.solution:
Creatinine is partially secreted and never reabsorbed. Clearance of creatinine (CCr) can also be used to determine GFR. Since creatinine is secreted by the tubules, the clearance of creatinine will be slightly higher than inulin. Hence, it overestimates GFR. 

Inulin is completely filtered and never reabsorbed. Hence, it can be used for GFR estimation. 

Glucose is completely reabsorbed below the renal threshold (i.e ~180mg/dl) in PCT. 

PAH(para amino hippuric acid) at low plasma concentrations is completely filtered and secreted. Hence, it can be used for estimation of renal blood flow.

Effective renal plasma flow in this patient will be falsely low.

questions.text: Which of the following transporter is present in the ascending loop of Henle?
questions.solution:
Thick ascending limb of loop of Henle has Na+ - 2Cl- - K+ co transporter that cotransports one Na+, one K+, and 2Cl– from the tubular lumen into the tubu­lar cells. This is an example of secondary active trans­port.

Na+ is transported out of the cell into the interstitium by Na, K ATPase in the basolateral membrane of the cell.

Cl– exits in basolateral ClC–Kb Cl– channels. Barttin, a protein in the cell membrane, is essential for normal ClC–Kb function.

K+ moves from the cell to the interstitium and the tubular lumen by ROMK(renal outer medullary potassium channel) and other K+ channels.

 

Clinical correlation:

Bartter syndrome is caused by loss-of-function mutations in the gene for any of four key proteins: the Na–K–2Cl co-transporter, the ROMK K+ channel, the ClC–Kb Cl– channel, or Barttin.

It is characterized by

  • Chronic Na+ loss in the urine, with resultant hypovolemia
  • Hypokalaemia
  • Alkalosis

questions.text: Potassium is maximally absorbed in____
questions.solution:
Potassium is maximally absorbed in PCT. 

Potassium is freely filtered by the glomerulus. The bulk of filtered K+ is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule. In the proximal tubule, K+ absorption is primarily passive and proportional to Na+ and water through paracellular transport. 

K+ reabsorption in the thick ascending limb of Henle occurs through both transcellular (Na+- K+- 2Cl- cotransport) and paracellular pathways.

K+ secretion begins in the early distal convoluted tubule and progressively increases along the distal nephron into the cortical collecting duct . Most urinary K+ can be accounted for by K+ secretion mediated by principal cells. Under conditions of K+ depletion, reabsorption of K+ occurs in the collecting duct. 

It is the only electrolyte to be reabsorbed as well as secreted.

questions.text: Bicarbonate is reabsorbed across the luminal membrane with the help of ______
questions.solution:
Bicarbonate is reabsorbed at the luminal membrane in the form of CO2 and H2O with the help of Na+ - H+ exchanger.

In the tubular cell of the PCT, CO2 and H2O recombine with the help of carbonic anhydrase II, and then dissociate into H+ and HCO3-. From here, the H+ moves back into the tubular lumen via the Na+ - H+ exchanger while the HCO3- is reabsorbed at the basolateral membrane via the Na+ - HCO3- co-transporter.

choices.text: H+ is absorbed in proximal tubule
Amino acid is reabsorbed in proximal tubule

questions.solution:

Option A: Maximum reabsorption occurs in proximal tubule

Option B: Urea is reabsorbed and secreted. It is reabsorbed in PCT and in collecting duct. It is secreted in thin ascending loop of henle.

Option C: H+ is secreted in PCT as well as in collecting ducts.

questions.text: Which of the following occurs along with glucose transport into the cell?
questions.solution:
Sodium symport occurs along with glucose transport into the cell.

Sodium and glucose are co-transported across the luminal membrane of proximal tubular cells. This occurs via sodium glucose co-transporters (SGLT2 and SGLT1). The energy derived from the movement of Na+ is used to move glucose against its concentration gradient into the tubular cell. This is referred to as secondary active transport. 

The Na+ is then pumped out of the cell into the interstitium, and the glucose exits by facilitated diffusion via glucose transporter (GLUT)-2 along the basolateral membrane into the interstitial fluid.

Clinical correlation:

Fanconi-Bickel syndrome: Defective GLUT2

Isolated renal glycosuria: Defective SGLT2

questions.text: Normal renal threshold (g/L) and transport maxima (mg/min)  for glucose respectively are _______, _________
questions.solution:
The actual renal threshold is about 200 mg/dL (i.e., 2 g/L ) (1g/L=100mg/dl) and the transport maximum for glucose is 375 mg/min.

For substances that are actively reabsorbed or secreted, there is a limit to the rate at which the solute can be transported, which is referred to as the transport maximum. This limit is due to saturation of the specific transport systems involved. 

Normally, measurable glucose does not appear in the urine because essentially all the filtered glucose is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule.

The transport maximum for glucose is about 375 mg/min, whereas the filtered load of glucose is only about 125 mg/min. With large increases in GFR and/or plasma glucose concentration that increase the filtered load of glucose above 375 mg/min, the excess glucose filtered is not reabsorbed and passes into the urine.

When the plasma glucose concentration is 100 mg/100 ml and the filtered load is at its normal level (125 mg/min) there is no loss of glucose in the urine. However, when the plasma concentration of glucose rises above about 200 mg/100 ml, increasing the filtered load to about 250 mg/min, a small amount of glucose begins to appear in the urine. This point is termed as the threshold for glucose.

Splay is due to separation between filtered load and exceretion. It occurs due to different transport maximums of different nephrons.

questions.text: The image of PAH excretion is depicted below. Match the labellings.

choices.text: a. Filtered, b. Excreted, c. Tm, d. Secreted
a. Filtered, b. Secreted, c. Tm, d. Excreted
a. Secreted, b. Filtered, c. Tm, d. Excreted
a. Excreted, b. Filtered, c. Tm, d. Secreted

questions.solution:
The labellings depticed are a. Filtered, b. Secreted, c. Tm, d. Excreted

Filtered Load: The filtered load of PAH increases linearly as the unbound concentration of PAH increases (filtered load = GFR.  [P]PAH).

Secretion: At low concentrations of PAH, many carriers are available and secretion increases linearly as the plasma concentration increases. When the PAH concentration increases to a level where the carriers are saturated, Tm is reached. After this point, no matter how much the PAH concentration increases, there can be no further increase in the secretion rate.

Excretion. For a secreted substance such as PAH, excretion is the sum of filtration and secretion. At low PAH concentrations (below Tm), excretion increases steeply with increases in plasma PAH concentration because both filtration and secretion are increasing. At PAH concentrations above Tm, excretion increases less steeply (and parallels the curve for filtration) because only the filtration component increases as concentration increases; secretion is already saturated.

questions.text: In a patient with uncontrolled diabetes, what is the value of plasma clearance of glucose?
questions.solution:
In uncontrolled diabetes, the plasma clearance of glucose is greater than zero. 

Normally, all the glucose that is filtered is reabsorbed and no glucose is excreted in the urine. Hence, the clearance is zero. In uncontrolled diabetes, since the plasma glucose concentration is greater than the renal threshold for reabsorption, excess glucose is excreted in the urine and the clearance is greater than zero.

Clearance of different substances can be shown in a graph as follows: 

The above graph depicts renal handling of glucose, inulin, and para-aminohippurate (PAH) and can be explained as follows:

Glucose clearance: Normally, all the glucose that is filtered is reabsorbed and no glucose is excreted in the urine. Hence, the clearance is zero. In uncontrolled diabetes, since the plasma glucose concentration is greater than the renal threshold for reabsorption, excess glucose is excreted in the urine and the clearance is greater than zero.

Inulin clearance: Inulin is freely filtered and is neither reabsorbed nor secreted. Hence, it is constant and equal to the glomerular filtration rate.

PAH clearance: PAH is both filtered and secreted. When plasma PAH is low, clearance is high. However, as plasma PAH rises above the threshold level for PAH secretion, clearance falls progressively.

questions.text: A patient has a â€‹blood glucose level of 200 mg/dL and GFR of 90 ml/min. What is the amount of glucose excreted if the transport maximum of the patient is as shown below?
questions.solution:
The amount of glucose excreted in the above scenario is 30 mg/min.

Calculation:

Step 1: Calculate total filtered glucose:

In this question,

  • GFR = 90 ml/min
  • Plasma glucose concentration = 200 mg/dL= 2 mg/ml (1 dL=100 ml).
  • Total filtered glucose = GFR X Plasma glucose concentration.

                               = 90 ml/min X 2 mg/ml
                               = 180 mg/min.

Step 2: Check transport maximum:

In the above question transport maximum is 150 mg/min.

Step 3: Calculate the excretion:

Excretion = Total filtered glucose - Total reabsorbed glucose (Transport Maximum)

  = 180-150 mg/min
  = 30 mg/min

questions.text: The mechanism by which majority of water is reabsorbed in PCT is
questions.solution:
Water reabsorption in PCT mainly occurs by osmosis.

The proximal tubule reabsorbs 67% of the filtered water. The driving force for water reabsorption is a transtubular osmotic gradient established by reabsorption of solutes.

questions.text: A dehydrated patient is excreting hypertonic urine. Absorption of water in which part of the nephron causes this?
questions.solution:
Hypertonic urine is excreted due to absorption of water in collecting duct.

The final concentration of urine is determined by the amount of water reabsorption that occurs in the collecting ducts. The changes in osmolarity of the urine (hypo/hypertonic) depends on the amount of ADH (vasopressin) acting on the collecting ducts.

The basic requirements for forming a concentrated urine (hypertonic urine) are

  • A high level of ADH, which increases the permeability of the distal tubules and collecting ducts to water, thereby allowing these tubular segments to avidly reabsorb water.
  • A high osmolarity of the renal medullary interstitial fluid, which provides the osmotic gradient necessary for water reabsorption to occur in the presence of high levels of ADH.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes insipidus is prescribed vasopressin. This drug has its maximum effect on which part of the renal tubule?
questions.solution:
Vasopressin has the maximum effect on the collecting ducts.

Vasopressin acts by inserting aquaporin 2 present in cytoplasmic vesicles of principal cells on to the apical membrane. The effect is mediated via the vasopressin V2 receptor, cyclic adenosine 5-monophosphate (cAMP), and protein kinase A. When vasopressin is absent, the collecting duct epithelium is relatively impermeable to water.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about free water clearance?
questions.solution:
Free water clearance is regulated by ADH.

Free water clearance is defined as the amount of solute-free water generated by the kidneys, either when dilute urine or when concentrated urine is formed.

Free-water clearance is positive, when excess water is being excreted (dilute urine).

Free-water clearance is negative, when excess solutes are being removed and water is being conserved (concentrated urine).

questions.solution:
Patient A shows positive free water clearance B is isotonic C shows negative free water clearance.

Patient A has positive free-water clearance, since excess water is being excreted (dilute urine).

Patient C has negative free-water clearance, since excess solutes are being removed and water is being conserved (concentrated urine).

questions.text: The average urine osmolality in mosm/kg is _____.
questions.solution:
The average urine osmolality is 100-800 mosm/kg.

The question specifies average urine osmolality not the range of osmolality; therefore, even though human urine osmolality can reach 1400 mOsm/L, the best answer is the given answer.

questions.text: What are the requirements for a patient to excrete concentrated urine?

choices.text: High ADH levels and hypoosmolar renal medulla
Low ADH levels and hypoosmolar renal medulla
High ADH levels and hyperosmolar renal medulla
Low ADH levels and hyperosmolar renal medulla

questions.solution:
The requirements for excreting concentrated urine are high ADH levels and hyperosmolar renal medulla. 

A high level of ADH, which increases the permeability of the distal tubules and collecting ducts to water, thereby allowing these tubular segments to avidly reabsorb water, and a high osmolarity of the renal medullary interstitial fluid, which provides the osmotic gradient necessary for water reabsorption to occur in the presence of high levels of ADH.

questions.text: Maximum osmotic gradient is found in____
questions.solution: Maximum osmotic gradient is found in the inner medulla. The gradient of osmolarity from the cortex (300 mosm/L) to the inner medulla (1200 mosm/L) is produced by the loops of Henle as countercurrent multipliers and maintained by operation of the vasa recta as countercurrent exchangers.

questions.text: Hyperosmolarity of renal medulla is due to____
questions.solution:
Hyperosmolarity of the medullary interstitium is mainly due to NaCl and urea.

The major factors that contribute to the buildup of solute concentration into the renal medulla are 

  • Active transport of Na+ and co-transport of K+, Cl-, and other ions out of the thick portion of the ascending limb of the loop of Henle into the medullary interstitium.
  • Active transport of ions from the collecting ducts into the medullary interstitium.
  • Facilitated diffusion of urea from the inner medullary collecting ducts into the medullary interstitium.
  • Diffusion of only small amounts of water from the medullary tubules into the medullary interstitium

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the countercurrent mechanism?

choices.text: Descending limb of loop of Henle

questions.solution:
Proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) does not play a role in countercurrent mechanism.

The countercurrent mechanism consists of 2 components: 

  1. Countercurrent multiplier: 
        a. Absorption of water via Aquaporin 1 in thin descending limb 
            b. Active transport of Na+- K+- 2Cl- in thick ascending limb
        c. Flow of fluid from PCT to DCT
       
  2. Countercurrent exchanger: Vasa recta are involved in this process. They help in maintaining the osmotic gradient in the renal medulla. This is a passive process.

questions.text: Maximum osmolality that can be reached at the tip of medulla is proportional to

choices.text: Distribution of Na-K-2Cl channel in the thick ascending loop of Henle
Permeability of descending loop to water

questions.solution:
The maximum osmolality that can be reached at the tip of the medulla is proportional to the length of the loop of Henle, because the Loop of Henle acts as Countercurrent multiplier to maitain the gradient in medulla. Greater is the length of loop of Henle, greater will be the osmolality that can be reached at the tip of the medulla. 

In case of juxtamedullary nephrons with longer loops and thin ascending limbs, the osmotic gradient is spread over a greater distance and the osmolality at the tip of the loop is greater.

questions.text: Counter current blood flow is seen in all except_____
questions.solution:
The eye does not have a countercurrent blood flow system.

Heat and substances, including gases, steroids and peptide hormones, can pass from venous blood, interstitial fluid and lymph to the arterial blood; the process is called local counter-current transfer.

Examples of countercurrent blood flow

  • Heat exchange between the arteries and venae comitantes of the limbs.
  • Vasa recta in the kidneys
  • Testes
  • Small intestine

questions.text: All of the following are components responsible for the countercurrent mechanism in the kidney except _____.

choices.text: Sodium outflow in thick ascending limb
Water outflow in thin descending limb
Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb
Flow of tubular fluid from PCT to DCT

questions.solution:
Thin ascending limb is not a component of the countercurrent mechanism. 

The loop of Henle function as countercurrent multipliers and vasa recta as countercurrent exchangers.

The functioning of the loop of Henle depends upon:

  1. High permeability of the thin descending limb to water ( via aquaporin-1)
  2. Active transport of Na+ and Cl- from the thick ascending limb
  3. Inflow of tubular fluid from proximal tubule and outflow to the distal tubule.

Note: The thin ascending limbs of juxtamedullary nephrons are permeable to Na+ and Cl- and hence do contribute passively to countercurrent multiplication. However, among the options provided, Option C is the best answer as the other options are directly responsible for the countercurrent mechanism.

questions.text: Which of the following is the diluting segment of the kidney?
questions.solution:
The ascending thick limb of the loop of Henle is called the diluting segment.

In the ascending limb, there is the movement of Na+ and Cl– out of the tubular lumen, and the tubular fluid becomes more dilute.

When the fluid reaches the top of the ascending limb, it becomes hypotonic to plasma.

questions.text: Macula densa is formed by which part of the nephron?
questions.solution:
Macula densa is formed by specialized tubular epithelial cells of the distal convoluted tubule.

The juxtaglomerular apparatus consists of the following parts:

  • Macula densa: At the end of the thick ascending limb of Henle, and at the beginning of the distal tubule, the tubular epithelial cells are specialized to form the macula densa. They detect sodium concentration of the fluid in the tubule (chemoreceptor). In response to elevated sodium, the macula densa cells trigger the contraction of the afferent arteriole, reducing the flow of blood to the glomerulus and the glomerular filtration rate. This happens as follows: When there is increased sodium, there is increased sodium-potassium ATPase activity which leads to increased ATP hydrolysis causing more adenosine formation. The adenosine receptors on the macula densa cells stimulate it to release more calcium, so that there is vasoconstriction of the afferent arteriole, thereby decreasing the GFR.
  • Lacis cells: Extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole.
  • Granular cells/JG cells: Modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole, they secrete renin. Fall in pressure in afferent arteriole stimulates renin release (mechanoreceptor), which, in turn, increases blood pressure.
